awd_titl_txt: Ethane Measurements in the Intermediate Depth South Pole Ice Core (SPICECORE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Aydin/1644245

This award supports a project to measure ethane in ice core air extracted from the recently drilled intermediate depth South Pole ice core (SPICECORE). Ethane is an abundant hydrocarbon in the atmosphere. The ice core samples that will be used in this analysis will span about 150 years before present to about 55,000 years before present and therefore, ethane emissions linked to human activities are not a subject of this study. The study will focus on quantifying the variability in the natural sources of ethane and the processes that govern its removal from the atmosphere. A long-term ice core ethane record will provide new knowledge on the chemistry of Earth?s atmosphere during time periods when human influence was either much smaller than present day or non-existent. The broader impacts of this work include education and training of students and a contribution to a better understanding of the chemistry of the atmosphere in the past and how it has been impacted by past changes in climate.
 
Natural sources that emit ethane are both geologic (e.g. seeps, vents, mud volcanoes etc.) and pyrogenic (wild fires) which is commonly called biomass burning. Ethane is removed from the atmosphere via oxidation reactions. The ice core ethane measurements have great potential as a proxy for gaseous emissions from biomass burning. This is especially true for time periods preceding the industrial revolution when atmospheric variability of trace gases was largely controlled by natural processes. Another objective of this study is to improve understanding of the causes of atmospheric methane variability apparent which are in the existing ice core records. Methane is a simpler hydrocarbon than ethane and more abundant in the atmosphere. Even though the project does not include any methane measurements; the commonalities between the sources and removal of atmospheric ethane and methane mean that ethane measurements can be used to gain insight into the causes of changes in atmospheric methane levels. The broader impacts of the project include partial support for one Ph.D. student and support for undergraduate researchers at UC Irvine. The PIs group currently has 4 undergraduate researchers. The PI and the graduate students in the UCI ice core laboratory regularly participate in on- and off-campus activities such as laboratory tours and lectures directed towards educating high-school students and science teachers, and the local community at large about the scientific value of polar ice cores as an environmental record of our planet's past. The results of this research will be disseminated via peer-review publications and will contribute to policy-relevant activities such as the IPCC Climate Assessment. Data resulting from this project will be archived in a national data repository. This award does not have field work in Antarctica.

por.por_cntn:
Polar ice sheets contain ancient air that can be analyzed to determine the past atmospheric composition of the Earth. Ice cores drilled at polar ice sheets are later sampled for atmospheric gas analysis. This grant funded the ice core research laboratory at the University of California, Irvine (UCI) to analyze air extracted from a new ice core drilled at the South Pole, Antarctica (SPC14 ice core), which provides an atmospheric record that spans the last 52,000 years. 

The UCI ice core research laboratory specializes in measurements of atmospheric gases that are found at extremely low levels called ultra-trace gases. The ambient concentrations of ultra-trace gases range from 1000 molecules per one trillion air molecules all the way down to 1 molecule per one trillion air molecules. Our aim is to use the ancient air trapped in the polar ice sheets to determine how the atmospheric concentrations of ultra-trace gases change over time. Atmospheric concentrations of gases can vary over time because of changes in the emissions into and removal from the atmosphere, providing information on the global environmental changes that take place on our planet. The time scales of interest range from 100 years before present to hundreds of thousands of years before present. The primary objective of this project was to make measurements two ultra-trace level gases - ethane (C2H6) and acetylene (C2H2) - using samples from the length of the SPC14 ice core. 

Ethane is the most abundant hydrocarbon (organic compounds containing only hydrogen and carbon atoms) in the atmosphere after methane, although there is roughly 1000 times more methane in the atmosphere than ethane. The lower concentrations are because of lower emissions and faster removal; the atmospheric oxidation of ethane is much faster than methane. Today, most of the ethane in the atmosphere is emitted during fossil-fuel production and use. The ice core measurements are from periods when there was no fossil fuel production and use. Wildfires and other types of open burning have been the most important source of ethane into the atmosphere prior to the industrial revolution. Acetylene (ethyne) is another hydrocarbon that is produced during combustion. Like ethane, the only significant source of acetylene into the preindustrial atmosphere is fires. Ice core records of both of these gases provide information on past fire variability. Fires are an important source of many other trace gases and aerosols, thus impact atmospheric chemistry and global climate.     

Prior to this project, the existing ice core data from Antarctica for ethane and acetylene were limited to the last 1,000 years before present day. With the measurements conducted under this project, we generated ice core records of ethane and acetylene that go back 52,000 years before present, covering periods of large natural climate change. The last 52,000 years include about 30,000 years of the last glacial period, the transition from the glacial (cold) to interglacial (warm) conditions that occurred between 20,000 to 11,000 years ago, and the last interglacial period named the Holocene. These are the first-ever measurements of ethane and acetylene in any ice core at unprecedented quality and temporal extent. 

The most prominent feature of the data from this project is that acetylene levels during the last glacial period were 4-5 times lower than during the Holocene and there were dramatic increases in the acetylene levels over Antarctica during the transition period from glacial climate conditions to interglacial climate conditions. During the Holocene, both acetylene and ethane display prominent maximum concentrations about 1,000 years before present.

These results indicate that there were large changes in global fire regimes during the transition from the last glacial period to the Holocene and also during the Holocene. These are novel findings that have implications for all atmospheric trace gases emitted from wildfires, including gases with very large greenhouse warming potentials such as methane and carbon dioxide. The results will provide previously unavailable constraints on fire variability over long time periods and the interaction between global climate and fires. The project resulted in two peer-reviewed research articles so far with more in the works, and numerous presentations in national meetings. 

This project also had major educational and outreach impacts. It supported the education and dissertation research of a first-generation graduate student at the UCI. It contributed to the education and training of junior level researchers, including one undergraduate student who received extensive hands-on laboratory research experience and who is now starting graduate school to pursue a PhD degree. During the grant period, the UCI ice core laboratory participated in various outreach activities geared towards introducing teachers and students of local high schools and middles schools to cutting edge polar research. The outreach activities involved presentations, laboratory tours, and experimental demonstrations that were led by the PI and the junior researchers involved in the project.
